ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: 5-10 depending on test schedule
Having the homework assigned on tuesday and due on thursday is difficult. I spend 1-4 hours outside of class on this class.
Weekly homework assignments increased the work load. Probably about 2 hours a week, would have been more if i did all of the readings. Considerably more the weeks that I was studying for exams.
4 hours a week
On regular weeks, I spent about 3 hours outside of the classroom on this course. On exam weeks, I spent about 36 hours outside of the classroom on this course.
I typically spent an hour or two doing the readings, and about two hours for each of the homework assignments. However, I studied for four straight days for both of the exams.
6hrs
2-3 hours/week - weekly homework assignments and readings.
about five

5 hours during normal lecture weeks and numerous days of study before midterm and final. The midterm and final were very challenging and required a great amount of hours every day leading up to the exams to be spent on studying the material.
I spent about 5 hours a week on the course normally and when there was an exam I spent about 20 hours studying for the exam.
2 hours.A LOT more before midterm and final exams.

I would say about 2 evenings a week. One evening I would pre-read the assigned readings for the lecture (about 1-1.5 hours) and then another night I would do the assigned homework and readings (~5 hours). So in total about 6-7 hours per week additionally to the 3 hours per week in class.
6 hours per week

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: This class is excellent and one of the best I have taken here at Yale

The course was very informative. I would have liked to learn about different cultures and how their rates of chronic disease in relation to nutrition differ from ours.Weakness -- Having the homework assigned on tuesday and due on thursday is difficult. I was not able to spend adequate time on the assignment and so I rushed through and did not learn as much as I could have.
very practical information whether or not nutrition is your specialty. we all eat a lot of food, and it is interesting to know the current research that is out there, as well as its short comings.

The course is excellent.The only suggestion would be to increase the length of time that students have to work on homework assignments. A brief turnaround (less than 2 days) is extremely difficult with other time constraints.

The organization of the class by disease was great. The lecture/discussion division was also a great way to review material, and the debates and such in section were very helpful. Sometimes the slides were hard to print since they were not black and white, but the course was otherwise great!
Overall, the class was GREAT! It's great to learn about the truth about nutrition stuff! It can be such a complicated topic. I wouldn't change the class!
The only issue I had with the curriculum was the huge emphasis on cancer...

I found the course very beneficial and informative. I liked the ways in which the course was presented in power point format with notes for the students. I also liked the way the discussion session was set up. I found the homework to be useful, and I liked the midterm and final review guides as I feel like they provided a good overview of what material to study for the exams.
Excellent course. Dr. Mayne is amazing. The pacing of the course in perfect and the tests are fair.

I loved this class!!! I really did -- and I've been running around spewing nutrition information and bitching about how bad trans fats are since I've been home. I went into the class knowing a good deal about personal nutrition, and I'd had some experience working with issues related to nutrition and public policy, but nearly everything that was presented in the class was new to me. It was incredibly interesting, so well organized, and very well-presented. Even though lecture was at 9 in the morning, I didn't mind going. And yes, I did spend a huge amount of time studying for the exams, but because I liked the material, it could have been a lot worse.When I saw the syllabus, I thought that it was a bit strange that we were going to spend three lectures discussing cancer, when there are so many other nutritional issues (especially obesity! the obesity epidemic!), but now that the class is over, I can see why we did, and I think it really made sense. Obesity is obviously an issue, but it's one specific issueand there is only so much you can say unless you turn it into a discussion about our culture, whereas cancer is really more of an umbrella term for a huge number of diseases, all with varied causes, treatments, and prognoses. I kind of wished we'd had one more lecture on the public policy side -- the supplement lecture was SO interesting, and I'd imagine that there are probably some other nutritional issues that are handled in some insane way by the government. The only negative was that I didn't really like the guest speaker on osteoperosis -- she wasn't particularly organized and clear (which is one of Dr. Mayne's strengths), so I didn't really think that having an outside expert was necessary.There really was only one part of the class that bothered me, and it's actually a very small thing, but I would like to mention it, as I'd imagine that this issue wasn't unique to me. I was pretty anxious when I heard that we had to do the nutritional assessment. I completely understand why we did it, and I think it is a great way to really convey just how difficult it is to conduct nutrition research. However, I have struggled with eating issues for ten years, and knowing this assignment was coming just hung over my head. I really did not want to make an issue out of it unless I really felt I needed to, so I logged on and entered a day's worth of information, and printed out what I needed. That was alright, as finding out what the emotions would look like having to do with actual nutritional intake wasn't my concern. But then, at the end of the three days, I went to print out the last sheet, and when I saw the calorie counts, I really flipped out. I hadn't expected to see that, and it was exactly what I was worried about seeing. I fought hard to stop counting calories, and now it is really awful for me to see numbers. Of course at that point, I was mad at myself for not saying something, but it was too late. So, that said. I think that it's important that the information we will see in the output be explained in class when we start the assignment, and if Dr. Mayne were to say that if this was going to be a problem for anyone, to let her know, that would be really great. If I'd known what that last page was going to show me, I never would have printed it out...but I was completely fine actually doing the day-to-day analysis. I think that i'd be great if there was a way to avoid having to print that last page for anyone who knew it was going to be a triggering problem for them.Ironically however....a class (or even half of a class) discussing eating disorders and their lasting health effects would be interesting and important. It's such a huge issue in our society, and even though people know the symptoms of the disorders, their lasting impacts are never discussed.
great course
A fantastic course and very detailed information on a whole spectrum of nutrition topics and how they influence chronic disease in the United States.
I learned so much this semester in the course. I thought the course was interesting and up to date.

This is an excellent course with an amazing professor. It is a very well organized course and there are many different topics covered. I learned a great deal of information this semester and feel very comfortable with nutrition, the policy, and how the guidelines and recommendations are set. The course prepares you to critique studies and find meaningful associations. Not only do you learn about nutrition but how nutrition is rooted in chronic disease and how it can be used for prevention.
The course was extremely well structured and presented. The material was up-to-date and interesting and applicable to the course.
Lectures were amazing. Guest lecture was OK. Discussion sections were helpful.

Strengths:- Prof Mayne - excellent lecture style, very interested in the topic herself and that made class that much more interesting.- Stephanie, the TA was wonderful as well - dedicated to teaching, always available, very interested in the subject matter herself.- Overall, an excellent review of nutrition literature in relation to chronic diseases.- Well chosen lecture topics and well prepared lectures.- Focus on prevention.- Great review of study design.Weaknesses:- Only 36 hours (in the middle of the week) to do homework assignments which were not insignificant.

This is a terrific class - very interesting subject, great professor, a particularly well run course. Because of the wealth of material you cover a lot of ground, but Dr. Mayne leads you through the literature in a clear and objective way.

This was a great course for anyone who is interested in nutrition and wellness. You learn a great deal about many studies that have been conducted in this field. The lectures were also very interesting and kept student's attention. You would be surprised to learn many of the details about the effect of one's diet and lifestyle decisions on their overall health.

The course was great; provided a really comprehensive overview of both the scientific and legislative/policy aspects of nutrition. By the end of the semester, I felt much more comfortable about my ability to critique nutritional epidemiology studies and the connection between observational studies and randomized clinical trials. Also inspired me to pursue policy specifically relating to nutrition.

This is a great comprehensive course on nutrition and chronic diseases. The professor does an amazing job going through the literature, past and current, and ties it all together at the end with policy and communication of health information.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Susan Mayne  Dr. Mayne is probably the strongest and most knowledgable lecturer I have had.
Instructor: Susan Mayne  She was great, very knowledgeable and a great speaker.

Instructor: Susan Mayne  I was VERY IMPRESSED by the Professor Mayne's PPT skills. There are few professors at EPH who use this medium so effectively. She is very knowledgeable in this subject area and it was a treat to take this class with her.
Instructor: Susan Mayne  Excellent. No room for improvement.

Instructor: Susan Mayne  The instructor moved through an immense amount of material, offering students a ton of resources and knowledge. This was great because students have varying interests and this way they were getting a sense of everything, even if they would not pursue that given disease or related studies. The powerpoints were organized and full of information.One request would be to post readings/assignments sooner.
Instructor: Susan Mayne  She was great instructor with a great amount of experience working in the nutrition field. She presented the information VERY clearly.
Instructor: Susan Mayne  Great lecturer, really knows her stuff.
Instructor: Susan Mayne  Dr. Mayne is very knowledgeable about the subject and I cannot think of any ways by which her teaching can be improved.

Instructor: Susan Mayne  Dr. Mayne is great.....and SO SO SO scary smart!!! She is incredibly knowledgeable, and knows the answer to nearly every question, and if she wasn't sure, she would say that she wasn't an expert in that specific area, which is such a great thing to do! There are a lot of people out there (not just professors!) who won't say if they're not sure about something, and when someone actually does say that, it's not only a great trait, but it also means that when there is an answer, you know for sure that it's right. The lectures were so well organized, the class flow in terms of subjects worked very well, and I really appreciated that she always showed us both sides of an issue.In addition, I think it was so great that she came to our discussion groups -- I haven't had a professor who has done that before, and it just showed her commitment to the course and that she was interested in what we had to say.
Instructor: Susan Mayne  very good lecturer, very organized, approachable

Instructor: Susan Mayne  Dr. Mayne is one of the best professors I've had. She has an impeccable command of the information and epidemiology of disease and nutrition, a fantastic lecturer, and passionate investigator. I have an immense amount of respect for her.
Instructor: Susan Mayne  Dr. Mayne was very knowlegeable and I enjoyed her as an instructor. She was one of my favorite professors.

Instructor: Susan Mayne  Dr. Susan Mayne is the best professor I have had at Yale. I am not in the CDE concentration, but she is such a powerful and brilliant professor that it makes me wish I could have the chance to take more courses with her. She has direct experience and provides clear examples and has devisedthe course to have challenging assignments and exams. She has made this course my favorite class of the semester.

Instructor: Susan Mayne  Dr. Mayne was an excellent instructor. All of her lectures were well organized, designed and presented. She had a knack for adding anecdotes to make the topics interesting and also presented striking evidence to support many of the topics.
Instructor: Susan Mayne  Professor Mayne is a stellar lecturer. She is absolutely amazing at explaining complex concepts in a simple, easy to understand way. I enjoyed her lectures very much.

Instructor: Susan Mayne  - Prof Mayne has a wonderful, fluid lecture style. She is very interested in the topic herself and that made class fascinating for all ofus! She is very approachable, sensitive to different students points of view, and answered all of the questions asked in class and outside of class. She created a comprehensive lectures series throughout the semester and provided us with a wonderful review of the literature. I would highly recommend this course to others and would very much enjoy taking another class with Dr. Mayne myself. Overall, an outstanding professor!
Instructor: Susan Mayne  Excellent - extremely knowledgeable, clear, a pleasure to listen to.

Instructor: Susan Mayne  Dr. Mayne is the perfect instructor for this course. She is an expert in the field and is on many boards that are involved in creating the newest dietary guidelines. She can give you first hand information from ground zero and does so in a manner that everyone can comprehend. Not only does she engage all of her students, she strives to help them as much as possible outside the classroom.

Instructor: Susan Mayne  Dr. Mayne's lectures are a pleasure to listen to; she is an extremely engaging and fluid lecturer. Her slides are also extremely helpful, particularly the slides on nutrition labeling and policy.Dr. Mayne is also very good at explaining concepts and emphasizing important big picture perspectives.The course was really fantastic. Perhaps the only way it could be improved is to have the exam review sheets be more detailed to help prepare for exams. Also, during the policy lecture, would be helpful to have some discussion about the media interprets nutrition research, and what public health professionals can do to dispel media misinformation and promote awareness of nutrition.

Instructor: Susan Mayne  Professor Mayne is a great instructor and is so knowledgeable in the field of nutrition. She's very responsive to students and really takes the time to answer questions during lectures to make sure the material is well-understood.

narratives.question_text: If this course included instruction by a teaching assistant (TA), please evaluate the TA here. What are the strengths and weaknesses and how might their teaching be improved? (Specify name of the TA).
comments: Stepahine did great, always ready to help and very good at running section
She did a good job of applying what we learned in lecture to our assignments and discussion.
Stephanie ScarmoStephanie led effective sections each week and was readily available out side of class as necessary. She and the professor worked very well together.
Excellent. Very devoted and very good at leading discussion sections.
Very strong - led discussion sections very well. Written feedback was also excellent.
Stephanie was a great help and provided great feedback on homeworks.
Stephanie was a good TA. She was well organized and presented us useful information during Thursday sessions.
Stephanie Scarmo was a really great TA. Engaging, and knows how to move along a class conversation.
The T.A. for this course was Stephanie Scarmo. I felt like she did an excellent job as a TA. She was very accessible to students and had a very good handle on the information.
Our TA was one of the best TAs that I've had at YSPH.

Stephanie was so fabulous!!! I know this was a really stressful semester for her, as she turned in and defended her dissertation, but I never would have known -- she led discussion section the day of her defense and was no different than any other week in terms of her level of attention. She was great in terms of answering questions and was a quick and thorough e-mail responder. I'm sorry for next year's class that they won't have her!
very helpful, approachable, organized and prepared to run discussion sessions smoothly
Stephanie Scarmo -is a very dedicated TA. Always prepared for our discussion section, gave valuable feedback on assignments, and provided us with information complimentary to the coursework.
Stephanie was so helpful and informative. I think she si a great TA.

Stephanie Scarmo is an excellent TA. She is organized and knows the material very well. During our discussion sections,which she led, she was always very well prepared and I felt that she could have taught the material because she was great at directing discussion and facilitating questions. She was always available outside of class and always very helpful.

Stephanie Scarmo was a great TA. She was very knowledgeable in the area and led the discussion sections with ease. She was always well prepared with interesting tasks and information to help us better understand some of the societal and industry implications of the evidence and theory we learned in class.
Stephanie was great. She was always prepared and did a great job leading the discussion sections.

- Stephanie, the TA, was wonderful as well. She is highly dedicated to teaching and the class. She was always, always available, very interested in the subject matter herself, always smiling and happy to help. I think she is the best TA I have had in any class.
Stephanie did a very nice job as TA for the course.

Stephanie Scarmo was the TA for this course. She was very warm and easy to talk to. She really tried toget to know all of the students at a personal level. Was always there for extra help and guidance. Her discussion sections were a big help as well and allowed students to understand the assignments on a much deeper level.

The class TA Stephanie was wonderful! She was very patient and extremely clear in all of her explanations. Also very good with the discussion sections and encouraging student participation. Additionally, Stephanie was extremely responsive and responded to questions very quickly. It was apparent that she was very passionate about the subject matter. Stephanie should pursue teaching; would make an excellent teacher!!
The TA led very informative and helpful discussion sessions. She made herself available to students at all times, particularly around exams.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Absolutely, I loved this class
very interesting. i would recommend it for a general overview on nutritional research/recommendations for anyone.
Recommend very highly. It is a challenging and useful course.
Intensive and exciting overview of the scientific evidence on nutrition in relation to chronic disease. Highly recommended for anyone who has a professional or personal interest in this area.
Overall, I would say this is a GREAT course. This information is very relevant to both your personal and professional futures!

It's one of the best courses I've taken at EPH. The curriculum is up-to-date and interesting (although there's too much of a focus on cancer, I think), the professor was a terrific lecturer, and the TA was engaging, accessible, and great at moving along the conversation.

I feel like this course is an excellent course for students who are interested in nutrition, chronic disease, or both. Through this couse, students get a basic overview of nutrition, how it interracts with the body and influences chronic disease, and some policy changes that can be made as a result.
Take this class.

I would absolutely recommend it. The course is about different nutrients and how they effect risk of chronic diseases, and it's not limited to one disease type. I wouldn't consider it an overview class, but it's a bit of an overview of the ideas about nutrients and their role in diseases and disease prevention. Exams were fair (knock on wood! I haven't gotten my final grade yet!). But seriously, the questions were reasonable. Nothing out of left-field, nothing that we barely touched upon, etc. Dr. Mayne is a great professor and I learned so much information. It was definitely a positive experience for me :)
very interesting course, extremely useful information for health professions and personal life

An in depth look at nutrition and chronic disease in the US, including the biology all the way to policy. A combination of fantastic lectures, interesting topics, and relevance to epidemiology today makes this a must-take course. Dr. Mayne is a fantastic professor, but also has high expectations of her students. I have learned so much and was very motivated to study hard for this class.
I would highly recommend this course. It was my favorite this semester and I learned so much during lectures.

The course is excellent as is the professor. The material is interesting and you will learn a lot. This will easily become one of the best courses to take but also one of the more challenging courses to take. The mixture of both makes this class very successful.

This was a great course that discussed all of the main topics in nutrition related to chronic disease. It was a useful course that I feel I got a lot out of. I would definitely recommend it to students who are interested in chronic disease, but also to any student as I feel a lot of these topic are important to learn about for general health of the population as well.

This is an amazing course for students in any concentration. I would highly recommend students to take this class -- for both personal and professional purposes. I never knew that I could learn so much about nutrition and chronic disease. I would like to take another extension of this course.

This course is a comprehensive review of the current literature in nutrition as it relates to chronic disease. I would highly recommend this class to another student. It was a fascinating, very well taught course on an intriguing subject matter.
Highly recommended to anyone with interest.

I would definitely recommend this course to students who are interested in nutrition and the public health aspects of implementing a healthier environment for the world. This class would also be great for people to open their eyes to their own diets as well. Many people might be in denial about how poor their diet actually might be, but this course would inspire them to take action to change their lifestyle and those around them.

I would definitely recommend this class to another student, particularly students who do not have an extensive background in nutrition. Really provides a detailed overview of both the science behind nutrition, as well as how it relates to policy and legislation pertaining to nutrition.Would also tell students who are interested in pursuing clinical careers that this class provides a great background for someone who will be seeing patients and potentially giving patients advice pertaining to nutrition.
If you are interested in nutrition and how foods affect a person's health, I would highly recommendthis course!
